block.p: China ended martial law in Beijing, and within hours the United States announced that it was easing its blanket opposition to World Bank loans to China.
China ended martial law in Beijing, and within hours the United States announced that it was easing its blanket opposition to World Bank loans to China.
China ended martial law in Beijing, and within hours the United States announced that it was easing its blanket opposition to World Bank loans to China.
With martial law lifted, an eerie quiet in Beijing

Several East German leaders, three of the four non-Communist partners in the coalition Government, threatened to resign if the Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, does not hasten reforms and abandon efforts to create a new domestic security force.
Thousands held a rally in Lithuania one day before President Gorbachev is to visit the republic to assess the mood among Lithuanians.
Comecon says it needs to make big changes
Soviets still stocking ammunition, U.S. says
U.N., bowing to Soviets, halts its Baltic contacts
Bulgaria pledges an investigation of bizarre '78 killing
The Noriega case's head prosecutor has become the focus of questions concerning whether he is the right person to handle a trial of such monumental importance to the Bush Administration.
A U.S.-Panama anti-drug accord was signed. It pledged cooperation in efforts to crack down on narcotics trafficking and money laundering.
From dictator of Panama to dictator of fashion
U.S.-South Korea war games will be reduced in size, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea announced. The Pentagon cited budget restraints.
The U.N.'s role in Cambodia is ready to be sharply expanded, said a U.N. official. Under a proposal from Australia, the U.N. would administer Cambodia for at least a year.
Laos is seeking new sources of aid as the Communist countries that have been its principal benefactors since 1975 now have other preoccupations.
Sri Lanka's Muslim minority, fearful that its interests will be ignored in the granting of more autonomy to Tamil areas, is threatening to appeal to Islamic nations for support.
I.R.A. political aide charged in terror case
Israeli camping store offers tips from afar
The exclusionary rule, which prevents illegally obtained evidence from being used in a criminal trial, was reaffirmed by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 decision.
Campeau's American retailers, which include some of the nation's most famous department stores, said that they met a deadline for paying suppliers for December merchandise.
The effects of alcohol on women occur quicker than they do in men because women's stomachs are less able to neutralize it, scientists have found.
A Legionnaire's disease outbreak in Louisiana has been traced to a supermarket's automatic misting machine, leading stores around the country to shut off the devices used to keep produce fresh.
Washington at Work: Stanley Sporkin, the judge presiding over a prominent case involving Lincoln Savings, has had a highly visible and unpredictable Washington career.

U.S. space programs were criticized by Vice President Quayle, the head of the White House's National Space Council, who said that the programs take too long and cost too much. He also spoke about the need for new ideas and technology.
The crew of the space shuttle released a Navy communications satellite in orbit and sped toward their planned rendezvous with a satellite they hope to snatch and bring back to Earth.
U.S. to seek lower Federal role in transportation
Cost-sharing on acid rain by states assailed
Turnaround on farms as price of milk rises
Insurer denies issuing a check to Stuart
Flooding forces hundreds to flee as rainfall in Northwest eases
The Supreme Court overturned fines that a Federal judge imposed on four Yonkers City Councilmen who refused to vote for legislation needed to carry out a public housing plan.
Excerpts from Yonkers ruling: limits on power
Protesters are pleased, but housing to proceed

An elderly man's respirator was turned off by three of his children, who then physically held back doctors from reconnecting the life-support equipment, the police and officials at Kings County Hospital said. Prosecutors are weighing homicide charges.

Dr. Veronica Prego testified, calmly recounting her four years of terrifying uncertainty from the time she pricked her finger with an AIDS-contaminated needle to the day she learned she had contracted the disease.
Contender for health chief attacked over AIDS stances
The collapse of a cafeteria wall at a school near Newburgh, N.Y., last November, was partly the result of a flawed building design, a state commision concluded. Nine children died in the incident.
Leaking Exxon pipe ran through regulatory limbo
Court bars bid for drug therapy on demand
Albany's optimism wanes as budget shortfall grows
An office tower on Park Ave. will be rebuilt
In city buildings, rooms for play

The world's most expensive painting, van Gogh's ''Irises,'' is back on the market, said Sotheby's, which also disclosed that it was modifying its widely assailed policy on extending loans to art buyers.
Dance: Focus at the Joyce: men
Word and Image: ''Midstream'' by Le Anne Schreiber

N.C.A.A. rules on drug testing were passed that require random testing of players in major football programs for performance-enhancing drugs, and impose stiffer penalties for violators, in any sport, of the N.C.A.A.'s drug policies.
Column: Dave Anderson on the Hall of Fame
Football: At least one 49er is very unhappy
Therapists turn to pets in treating children
Johnny Sylvester, the inspiration for Babe Ruth heroics
A. M. Rosenthal: Passage from Ezekiel
Robert D. Hormats: In the East bloc, it's trade or fail
Leonid Fridman: America needs its nerds
